page.title: Right of expatriates to vote in their country of origin

revision.text:
The right of expatriates to vote in elections in their country of origin varies depending on the legislation of an expatriate’s country of origin. Some countries (such as [[France]]) grant their expatriate citizens unlimited voting rights, identical to those of citizens living in their home country. Other countries allow expatriate citizens to vote only for a certain number of years after leaving the country, after which they are no longer eligible to vote (e.g. 15 years for the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and 25 years for [[Germany]]). Other countries reserve the right vote solely to citizens living in that country, thereby stripping expatriate citizens of their voting rights once they leave their home country (such as [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], with extremely limited exceptions).
Expatriates' voting rights in local elections sometimes vary within individual countries, usually those with federal systems, such as [[Switzerland]] and the [[United States]]. For example, Swiss expatriates originally hailing from certain [[Cantons of Switzerland|cantons]] may vote in elections at cantonal level, while those from other cantons may not.<ref name=":1" /> The issue has been raised by [[European Union]] institutions, particularly in relation to citizens of one EU state resident in another.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2015/564379/EPRS_IDA(2015)564379_EN.pdf |format=PDF |title=Disenfranchisement of EU citizens resident abroad; Situation in national and European elections in EU Member States |publisher=European Parliamentary Research Service |first=Eva-Maria |last=Poptcheva |date=June 2015 |isbn=978-92-823-7548-8 |doi=10.2861/115885 |issue=PE 564.379 |accessdate=24 April 2018 |id=PE 564.379}}</ref>
As of 2006, 93 countries allowed their expatriate citizens to vote: 21 [[Africa]]n countries, 13 countries in the [[Americas]], 15 [[Asia]]n countries, 6 [[Oceania|Pacific]] countries and 36 [[Europe]]an countries.<ref name="globalirish">{{Cite web|url=http://www.globalirish.ie/issues/emigrant-voting/|title=External voting: a GlobalIrish.ie factsheet {{!}} globalirish.ie – about Irish emigration and the diaspora|website=www.globalirish.ie|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
According to an extensive and thorough research published in 2007 out of researched 214 countries and territories 115 had provisions for external voting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://aceproject.org/ace-en/topics/va/onePage|title=Voting from Abroad —|website=aceproject.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.idea.int/sites/default/files/publications/voting-from-abroad-the-international-idea-handbook.pdf|title=Voting from Abroad - The International IDEA Handbook|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Country-by-country breakdown ==
=== Australia === Australian citizens living abroad may vote if they register to vote within three years of leaving ''and'' intend to return to Australia within six years of leaving. Australians who were under 18 when they left Australia may vote if they intend to return to Australia within six years of their 18th birthday. Voting may be done by post or at an Australian embassy, consulate or high commission. Unlike for Australians living in Australia, voting is not [[Elections in Australia|compulsory]] for expatriate Australians.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aec.gov.au/enrolling_to_vote/overseas/|title=Living or going overseas|last=26|first=corporateName=Australian Electoral Commission; address=50 Marcus Clarke Street, Canberra ACT 2600; contact=13 23|website=Australian Electoral Commission|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-12-21}}</ref>
=== Austria === Austrian citizens living abroad may vote by post in Austrian presidential and parliamentary [[Elections in Austria|elections]], as well as referendums, with no expiry date. They must enrol on a dedicated foreign voters' register and must renew their registration every ten years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.help.gv.at/Portal.Node/hlpd/public/content/32/Seite.320510.html|title=Stimmabgabe im Ausland|last=Österreich|first=Republik|website=HELP.gv.at|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref>
=== Belgium === As of 2017, Belgian citizens living abroad can register to vote for elections to the [[Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Chamber of Representatives]] and the [[European Parliament]]. Once registered in a consular post (which is optional), the person is subject to [[compulsory voting]]. Expatriates cannot vote in regional or local elections.
Originally, the law of 18 December 1998 first gave Belgians living abroad the right to vote in federal elections (i.e. for the [[Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Chamber]] and [[Senate (Belgium)|Senate]]). However, the law was inadequate{{clarify|date=August 2018}} and not generally applied.
The law of 7 March 2002 improved the procedure. Belgians abroad could register in a [[Municipalities of Belgium|municipality]] of their choice, determining the constituency in which their vote would be cast. In practice, most votes were cast in the linguistically sensitive [[Brussels-Halle-Vilvoorde]] constituency.
The [[sixth Belgian state reform]] (ca. 2012), which also abolished the Brussels-Halle-Vilvoorde constituency and direct Senate elections, replaced the free choice by an objectively defined municipality (where the person last lived, or else further criteria apply).
The law of 17 November 2016 slightly changed the procedure, and also extended the right to vote for [[Elections to the European Parliament|European Parliament elections]] to Belgians living in a non-EU member state. Belgians living in another EU member state already had the right to vote on Belgian lists in European Parliament elections.
On 26 August 2016, the [[Michel Government|cabinet]] also approved the right to vote in regional elections; however, this change is subject to approval by [[Special law|special majority]] in parliament, causing the measure to stall.
=== Brazil === [[Brazil]]ian citizens living abroad aged between 18 and 70 must vote, as Brazil's policy of [[compulsory voting]] includes expatriate Brazilians.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tse.jus.br/eleitor/eleitor-no-exterior/votacao-no-exterior|title=Eleitor no exterior|website=www.tse.jus.br|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref> Voting is possible, but not mandatory, for Brazilian expatriates aged over 70 or under 18 (Brazil's minimum [[voting age]] is 16).
=== Canada === Canadian citizens living abroad can vote by post if they have lived outside Canada for less than five consecutive years. Only Canadians working for the Canadian government, a Canadian company or an international organisation in which Canada is involved are exempt from this expiry date.
Canadian citizens living abroad who are not eligible to vote by post may still vote regardless of how long they have lived abroad, but only if they return to Canada to vote in person.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elections.ca/content2.aspx?section=vote&dir=abro&document=index&lang=e|title=Voting from abroad|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref>
=== Chile === Chilean expatriates have the right to vote in [[Elections in Chile|presidential elections]] (primaries, first and second round) and national referenda in the consulate where they registered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Voto de chilenos en el exterior|url=https://www.servel.cl/voto-de-chilenos-en-el-exterior-2/|website=SERVEL|accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Guía legal sobre: Voto de chilenos en el extranjero|url=http://www.bcn.cl/leyfacil/recurso/voto-de-chilenos-en-el-extranjero|website=Ley Fácil|publisher=Library of the Chilean National Congress|accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref> The law allowing expatriate Chilean citizens the right to vote was presented by President [[Michelle Bachelet]] and approved by [[National Congress of Chile|Congress]] in August 2016. The [[Chilean presidential primaries, 2017|primaries]] for the [[Chilean general election, 2017|2017 presidential election]] were the first time that expatriates were allowed to vote.
=== Colombia ===
Regardless of their time living abroad, [[Colombia]]n expatriates enjoy full voting rights in national referendums, presidential and parliamentary elections. One member of the [[House of Representatives (Colombia)|House of Representatives]] comes from the international constituency and is elected exclusively by citizens living abroad. In order to vote, Colombian citizens have to register in their respective consulate or embassy in the established periods before the election dates.<ref>{{cite web|title=Los colombianos residentes en el exterior ya pueden acercarse a la embajada o consulado más cercano y realizar la inscripción de la cédula para participar en las Elecciones de 2018 |url=http://www.cancilleria.gov.co/newsroom/news/colombianos-residentes-exterior-ya-pueden-acercarse-embajada-o-consulado-cercano|accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref>
===Costa Rica===
Costa Rican citizens can vote for president and national referendums regardless of their time living abroad since Electoral Code's reform of 2010. They can't, however, vote in local elections which includes deputies and municipal authorities. The first time this was implemented was in the [[Costa Rican general election, 2014]]. Costa Ricans vote in the respective consulate or embassy and have to register their location a year before the election.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Arias|first1=L|title=Ticos living abroad can now register online to vote in 2018|url=http://www.ticotimes.net/2016/11/04/ticos-abroad-vote|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=The Tico Times|date=November 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Alvarado|first1=Laura|title=Costa Rican Embassy in the United States Explains How to Vote in the 2018 Elections|url=https://news.co.cr/costa-rica-embassy-united-states-regarding-2018-presidential-elections/70208/|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=The Costa Rica Star|date=January 28, 2018}}</ref>
=== France === [[France|French]] citizens living abroad enjoy full voting rights in presidential and parliamentary [[Elections in France|elections]], regardless of how long they have lived abroad.
France has a dedicated [[Assembly of French Citizens Abroad]], the president of which is the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Development (France)|French Foreign Minister]]. France also has a system of 11 [[constituencies for French residents overseas]], each of which are represented by a deputy who sits in the [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]].
=== Germany === Article 12(2)(1) of the Federal Voting Act<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/bwahlg/__12.html|title=BWahlG - Einzelnorm|website=www.gesetze-im-internet.de|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref> states that [[Germany|German]] citizens who live abroad and have no residence in Germany may vote in German [[Elections in Germany|parliamentary elections]] and European Parliament elections if:
a) they have resided in Germany for an uninterrupted period of at least three months since their 14th birthday and within the last 25 years; or
b) they have a close personal and direct relationship with German politics and are personally affected by political developments in Germany.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.konsularinfo.diplo.de/wahlen|title=Auswärtiges Amt Berlin - Allgemeine Informationen zur Wahlteilnahme aus dem Ausland|website=www.konsularinfo.diplo.de|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
=== India === Expatriate [[India]]n citizens have been allowed to vote in all [[Elections in India|Indian elections]] since 2010, provided that they have not acquired the citizenship of another country (India does not permit [[Multiple citizenship|dual nationality]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/nri/FAQ.pdf|title=Frequently Asked Questions|last=Electoral Commission of India|first=|date=|website=|access-date=23 March 2017}}</ref>
=== Ireland === {{main|Right of Irish expatriates to vote}} At most [[elections in the Republic of Ireland]] the [[electoral register]] is based on residential address, and the only nonresident voters are those serving abroad on government business; this includes [[Irish diplomatic missions|Irish diplomats]] and their spouses, and [[Defence Forces (Ireland)|Defence Forces]] and [[Garda Síochána]] personnel but not their spouses.<ref name="globalirish" /><ref>{{cite book|author=Oireachtas All-party committee on the Constitution|title=Seventh Progress Report: Parliament |url=https://www.constitution.ie/Documents/Oireachtas%207th-Report-Parliament%202002.pdf#pages=40|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020173339/https://www.constitution.ie/Documents/Oireachtas%207th-Report-Parliament%202002.pdf#pages=40|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-10-20|format=PDF|year=2002|pages=40–59 : 55 |chapter=Chapter 4: Northern Ireland and emigrant participation in national political life}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/government_in_ireland/elections_and_referenda/voting/registering_to_vote.html|title=Registering to vote|date=29 March 2018|pages=Overseas voters |nopp=Y|accessdate=23 April 2018 |publisher=Citizens Information Board |location=Dublin }}; {{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1992/act/23/enacted/en/print#sec7|title=Electoral Act, 1992|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|nopp=Y|pages=ss.7–14|accessdate=23 April 2018}}; {{cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/military-spouses-living-abroad-are-denied-vote-26290967.html|title=Military spouses living abroad are denied vote|last=Brady|first=Tom|date=16 May 2007|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=23 April 2018}}; {{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail2004032500013|title=Other Questions [9344/04] — Postal Voting|date=25 March 2004|work=Dáil Éireann Debates|publisher=Oireachtas|nopp=Y|pages=Vol.582 No.5 p.13 cc.1343–1344|accessdate=23 April 2018}}</ref> An exception is in elections to the [[Seanad Éireann|Seanad]] (upper house) for which graduates voting in the [[university constituency|university constituencies]] ([[National University of Ireland (constituency)|National University of Ireland]] and [[University of Dublin (constituency)|University of Dublin]]) may be nonresident.<ref name="globalirish" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/eng/Work_Of_The_Department/Protocol/Working_Group_on_Seanad_Reform/FINAL_Seanad_Reform_web_version.pdf#page=45 |format=PDF|title=Report|author=Working Group On Seanad Reform|year=2015|page=44|quote=non-resident graduates can register to vote in the university members elections at present |accessdate=23 April 2018}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1937/act/30/enacted/en/print#sec7|title=Seanad Electoral (University Members) Act, 1937|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|nopp=Y|pages=ss 7, 20|accessdate=23 April 2018}}</ref> Expatriates intending to return to Ireland within eighteen months may retain their Irish address for electoral purposes, but must be present to vote in person.<ref>Oireachtas All-party committee on the Constitution p.55</ref><ref name="hometovote_ireland">{{cite news|last1=Hickey|first1=Shane|title=The vote: returning emigrants warned of 18-month rule|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/abroad/the-vote-returning-emigrants-warned-of-18-month-rule-1.3505885|accessdate=24 May 2018|work=The Irish Times|date=24 May 2018}}; {{cite news|last1=Kenny|first1=Ciara|title=Illegal emigrant voting: How #HometoVote could backfire|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/abroad/illegal-emigrant-voting-how-hometovote-could-backfire-1.3385321|accessdate=24 May 2018|work=The Irish Times|date=10 February 2018}}</ref> Since the 1990s there have been proposals to allow emigrants to vote in elections to the [[Dáil Éireann|Dáil]] (lower house) or Seanad, generally via a dedicated ([[single transferable vote]] multi-seat) [[constituency]].<ref name="Honohan2011">{{cite journal|last=Honohan|first=Iseult|year=2011|title=Should Irish Emigrants have Votes? External Voting in Ireland|journal=Irish Political Studies|volume=26|issue=4|pages=545–561 : p.14 of preprint |issn=0790-7184|doi=10.1080/07907184.2011.619749|url=http://irserver.ucd.ie/bitstream/handle/10197/4346/Honohan_Irish_emigrants_voting_pre-print.pdf |format=PDF }}</ref> In 2017 the government agreed to allow expatriate citizens to vote in [[Irish presidential election|presidential election]]s and promised a [[Amendments to the Constitution of Ireland|constitutional referendum]] to be held alongside the [[Irish local elections, 2019|2019 local election]].<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://merrionstreet.ie/en/News-Room/Releases/Coveney_publishes_an_Options_Paper_on_extending_the_eligibility_for_citizens_resident_outside_the_State_to_vote_at_presidential_elections.html |title=Coveney publishes an Options Paper on extending the eligibility for citizens resident outside the State to vote at presidential elections |date=22 March 2017|work=MerrionStreet|publisher=Government of Ireland|accessdate=23 April 2018}}; {{Cite press release |url=http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/eng/News/Taoiseach's_Press_Releases/Announcement_by_the_Taoiseach_on_Voting_Rights_in_Presidential_Elections_for_Irish_Citizens_outside_the_State.html |title=Announcement by the Taoiseach on Voting Rights in Presidential Elections for Irish Citizens outside the State |last=Ruth |first=Maguire |publisher=Department of the Taoiseach |access-date=2017-03-23}}; {{cite web|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/wrans/?id=2018-04-17a.4040#g4046.r|title=Postal Voting|date=17 April 2018|work=Written answers|publisher=KildareStreet.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|quote=the proposed referendum on extending the franchise at presidential elections to Irish citizens resident outside the State which it is intended will be held on the same date as the local and European elections in late May/early June 2019}}</ref>
=== Italy === {{Main|Overseas constituencies of Italian Parliament}} [[Italy|Italian]] citizens living abroad retain the right to vote in Italian [[Elections in Italy|parliamentary elections]]. They may vote either by post or at an Italian consulate or embassy. However, for Italian citizens who live in a country which has no Italian diplomatic representation, the only way to vote is to travel to Italy to vote in person. Citizens who choose to do so are reimbursed by the Italian government for 75% of their travel costs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.conslondra.esteri.it/Consolato_Londra/Menu/I_Servizi/Per_i_cittadini/Servizi_elettorali/Elezioni_politiche/|title=Consolato Generale d'Italia in Londra|website=www.conslondra.esteri.it|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
The [[Italian Parliament]] reserves 18 seats for those [[expatriates|citizens residing abroad]]: there are twelve such seats in the Chamber of Deputies and six in the Senate of the Republic.
=== Japan === [[Japan]]ese citizens living abroad have been allowed to vote in [[National Diet|Diet]] [[Elections in Japan|elections]] since 2005, when the [[Supreme Court of Japan|Supreme Court]] ruled that a ban on eligible overseas Japanese citizens from voting was [[Constitutionality|unconstitutional]]. Citizens can vote either by post or at their local Japanese embassy or consulate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2005/09/20/editorials/counting-the-overseas-vote|title=Counting the overseas vote {{!}} The Japan Times|work=The Japan Times|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Luxembourg === [[Luxembourg]] citizens living abroad may vote in [[Elections in Luxembourg|parliamentary elections]] and referendums, but not local elections.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://elections.public.lu/fr/systeme-electoral/index.html|title=Système électoral|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref>
=== Malta === [[Malta|Maltese]] citizens may only vote if they are physically present in Malta on election day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.mt/en/Life%20Events/resformalities/Pages/Elections.aspx|title=Elections|website=www.gov.mt|language=en|access-date=2016-12-15}}</ref> There is no rule forbidding expatriate citizens from voting, but they may only vote if they return to Malta in person to do so, at their own expense. There have been attempts and petitions to allow Maltese citizens living abroad to vote by post.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130104/local/Expats-start-online-petition-to-let-us-vote-while-abroad-.451907|title=Expats start online petition to ‘let us vote while abroad’|last=Ltd|first=Allied Newspapers|newspaper=Times of Malta|access-date=2016-12-15}}</ref>
=== Namibia === Namibian citizens living abroad have been allowed to vote in national [[Elections in Namibia|elections]] since 2014, when amendments were made to the Electoral Act 2009, Namibian expatriates may vote at temporary registration points, usually set up at Namibian embassies or high commissions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.namibiahc.org.uk/resources/content/supplementary-registration-of-voters-2014.pdf|title=Supplementary registration of voters|last=|first=|date=|website=Namibian High Commission to the United Kingdom|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330194456/http://namibiahc.org.uk/resources/content/supplementary-registration-of-voters-2014.pdf|archive-date=2016-03-30|dead-url=yes|access-date=12 April 2017}}</ref>
=== Netherlands === [[Netherlands|Dutch]] citizens who live abroad (and have deregistered as Dutch residents) are allowed to vote in elections for the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] and for the European Parliament, but cannot vote in municipal or provincial elections. They must register as voters in order to vote from abroad.
=== New Zealand === [[New Zealand]] citizens living abroad have full voting rights with no expiry date as long as they have lived in New Zealand for at least one year continuously at some point in their lives and have visited New Zealand within the last three years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elections.org.nz/voters/get-ready-enrol-and-vote/enrol-and-vote-overseas|title=Enrol and Vote from Overseas|website=Electoral Commission|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref>
=== Philippines === Under Republic Act No. 9189 (also known as the Overseas Absentee Voting Act of 2003), [[Philippines|Filipino]] citizens living abroad are allowed to vote, with no expiry date.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dfa-oavs.gov.ph/|title=Welcome to the Official Website of the Overseas Absentee Voting Secretariat|website=www.dfa-oavs.gov.ph|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
=== Portugal === Article 49 of the [[Constitution of Portugal|Portuguese Constitution]] grants all [[Portugal|Portuguese]] citizens the right to vote, regardless of where they live.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.en.parlamento.pt/Legislation/CRP/Constitution7th.pdf|title=Constitution of the Republic of Portugal (official English translation)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=7 March 2016}}</ref>
Portugal has a ''Council of Portuguese Communities'' (Conselho das Comunidades Portuguesas), a consultative body which is part of the [[Government of Portugal|Portuguese government]] and represents the interests of Portuguese citizens living abroad.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cne.pt/content/conselho-das-comunidades-portuguesas|title=Conselho das Comunidades Portuguesas {{!}} Comissão Nacional de Eleições|website=www.cne.pt|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
=== Singapore === [[Singapore]]an citizens living abroad may vote in [[Presidential elections in Singapore|presidential]] and [[Parliamentary elections in Singapore|parliamentary elections]], with no expiry date. However, they may only vote in person at one of ten designated overseas [[Polling place|polling stations]], located in Australia, China (two polling stations: [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]]), Japan, Hong Kong, the United Arab Emirates, the United Kingdom and the United States (three polling stations: [[New York City]], [[San Francisco]] and [[Washington, D.C.]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eld.gov.sg/voters_ops.html|title=Singapore Elections Department - Overseas Polling Stations|last=ELD|website=www.eld.gov.sg|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> Each citizen is assigned to an overseas polling station depending on where they live. Expatriate citizens are also assigned a polling station in Singapore, where they can vote in person if they happen to be in Singapore on election day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eld.gov.sg/voters_overseas.html|title=Singapore Elections Department - Who Can Vote Overseas?|last=ELD|website=www.eld.gov.sg|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
=== South Africa === Pursuant to Chapter 1, Section 10 of Electoral Act 73 of 1998, [[South Africa]]n citizens living abroad retain the right to vote in national [[Elections in South Africa|elections]], with no expiry date. Expatriate citizens wishing to vote must do so in person at a South African embassy, consulate or high commission.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elections.org.za/content/For-Voters/How-to-register-and-vote-abroad/|title=Electoral Commission : How to register and vote abroad|website=www.elections.org.za|access-date=2016-12-21}}</ref>
=== Spain === Article 68, Section 5 of the [[Spanish Constitution of 1978|Spanish Constitution]] guarantees [[Spain|Spanish]] citizens living abroad the right to vote. They may do so either at a Spanish consulate or embassy, or by post.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.essex.ac.uk/armedcon/world/europe/western_europe/spain/SpainConstitution.pdf|title=Spanish Constitution (unofficial English translation)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=University of Essex|access-date=7 March 2016}}</ref>
Spain has a ''General Council of Spanish Citizenship Abroad'' (Consejo General de la Ciudadanía Española en el Exterior, CGCDE), an advisory body which represents the interests of Spanish citizens living abroad.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ciudadaniaexterior.empleo.gob.es/es/index.htm|title=Portal de la Ciudadanía Española en el Exterior: Secretaría General de Inmigración y Emigración.: Ciudadanía Española en el Exterior|website=www.ciudadaniaexterior.empleo.gob.es|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
=== Sweden === Swedish nationals living abroad are automatically entitled to vote in [[Riksdag]] elections and [[European Parliament]]ary [[Elections in Sweden|elections]] (for those living in another [[Member state of the European Union|EU Member State]]) up to ten years after leaving Sweden. There is no time limit to eligibility, but after the initial 10-year period has elapsed, Swedish expatriates must renew their electoral roll registration by filling out a form every 10 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.val.se/det_svenska_valsystemet/rostratt/utlandssvenskar/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-11-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906141536/http://www.val.se/det_svenska_valsystemet/rostratt/utlandssvenskar/index.html |archivedate=2017-09-06 |df= }}</ref> They cannot vote in either [[Counties of Sweden|county]] or [[Municipalities of Sweden|municipal]] elections. Voting take place either by post or at Swedish embassies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.val.se/det_svenska_valsystemet/rostratt/utlandssvenskar/index.html|title=För utlandssvenskar|last=|first=|date=|website=Valmyndigheten|language=sv|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906141536/http://www.val.se/det_svenska_valsystemet/rostratt/utlandssvenskar/index.html|archive-date=2017-09-06|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-09-10|df=}}</ref>
=== Switzerland === [[Switzerland|Swiss]] citizens living abroad may vote, with no expiry date, in [[Elections in Switzerland|elections]] for the [[National Council (Switzerland)|National Council]] (lower house of parliament) and in federal referendums, provided that they register with the relevant Swiss representation abroad. Their eligibility to vote in elections for the [[Council of States (Switzerland)|Council of States]] (upper house of parliament) and in [[Cantons of Switzerland|cantonal]] and [[Municipality|municipal]] elections depends on the law of the canton in which the person was registered before leaving Switzerland.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ch.ch/en/voting-rights/|title=Voting rights in Switzerland - www.ch.ch|website=www.ch.ch|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eda.admin.ch/eda/en/home/living-abroad/fifth-switzerland/voting-and-electoral-rights.html|title=Voting and electoral rights|website=www.eda.admin.ch|language=en|access-date=2018-02-07}}</ref>
=== Tunisia === [[Tunisia]]n expatriates have been granted the right to vote in presidential elections since 1988, and additionally in parliamentary elections since the [[Tunisian Revolution]] in 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s40878-016-0034-y|title=Thibaut Jaulin, Geographies of external voting: the Tunisian elections abroad since the 2011 Uprising, Comparative Migration Studies, Springer 2016}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === [[United Kingdom|British]] citizens living abroad may vote in [[Elections in the United Kingdom|UK general elections]], [[Referendums in the United Kingdom|referendums]] and [[Elections to the European Parliament|European Parliament elections]] for up to 15 years after leaving the UK. However, they may only do so if they were [[Electoral registration in the United Kingdom|registered to vote]] in the UK while living there. British expatriates who were under 18 at the time of leaving the UK may vote as long as their parent or guardian was registered to vote in the UK.
British expatriates are not allowed to vote in local elections or in elections for the devolved [[Scottish Parliament]] or [[National Assembly for Wales|Welsh]] or [[Northern Ireland Assembly|Northern Irish Assemblies]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aboutmyvote.co.uk/register-to-vote/british-citizens-living-abroad|title=Overseas voters|last=Commission|first=The Electoral|website=www.aboutmyvote.co.uk|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
In February 2018, the Overseas Electors Bill was presented to Parliament, with a view to abolishing the 15-year limit and the requirement to have registered to vote before leaving the UK. This would grant all British expatriates the unlimited right to vote, as long as they have lived in the UK at some point in their lives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-delivering-on-pledge-to-give-back-british-expats-the-right-to-vote|title=Government delivering on pledge to give back British expats the right to vote - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/chloe-smith-writes-about-votes-for-life-for-british-expats|title=Chloe Smith writes about votes for life for British expats - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref> The issue became a hotly debated topic among British expatriates who have lived in other EU Member States for more than 15 years and were thus barred from voting in the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|referendum on European Union membership]], despite arguably being more affected by the result than British people living in the UK.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thelocal.fr/20180209/uk-again-vows-to-give-brits-in-france-votes-for-life-but-is-it-too-late|title=UK again vows to give Brits in France 'votes for life' but is it all too late?|date=2018-02-09|access-date=2018-03-07|language=en}}</ref>
=== United States of America === [[United States|US]] citizens living abroad enjoy full voting rights, regardless of how long they have lived abroad. In addition, 36 [[U.S. state|states]], plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]], allow US citizens who have never resided in the US to vote in the respective state based on where their parent or legal guardian was last registered.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fvap.gov/citizen-voter/reside|title=Never Resided in the U.S.|website=www.fvap.gov|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>

[[File:Food Help Malawi Africa.jpeg|thumb|School feeding program in Malawi]]
School feeding programs have been defined by the World Bank as "targeted social safety nets that provide both educational and health benefits to the most vulnerable children, thereby increasing enrollment rates, reducing absenteeism, and improving [[food security]] at the household level".<ref name="scaling" /> Beyond improvements in access to food, school feeding programs also have a positive impact on nutritional status, gender equity, and educational status, each of which contributes to improving overall levels of country and human development.
While [[school meals]] are provided by the governments of most high and middle-income countries around the globe, the children who may benefit most from school feeding programs are in low-income countries that do not have government-provided school meals. School feeding in low-income countries often starts through funding by international organizations such as the [[United Nations World Food Programme]] or the [[World Bank]] or national governments through programs such as the [[McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program]]. However, some governments have first started school-feeding programs and then requested the help of these organizations and programs. Additionally, many countries have "graduated" from their dependency on foreign assistance by reshaping their school feeding programs to be country-led and self-supported.<ref name=RT>{{cite web|last=Bundy|first=Donald|title=Rethinking School Feeding|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EDUCATION/Resources/278200-1099079877269/547664-1099080042112/DID_School_Feeding.pdf|publisher=The World Bank|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref>
While there are school feeding programs in a number of countries, each program varies widely from country to country in design, implementation, and evaluation. Thus, literature reviews and studies often focus on a small number of countries, as school feeding is not a uniform unit of intervention and cannot be compared or assessed on an international scale.
==Need for school feeding programs==
According to the United Nations World Food Programme, 66 million primary school age children go hungry every day, with 23 million hungry children in [[Africa]] alone.<ref name="wfp">{{cite web|year=2009|title=School Meals|url=http://www.wfp.org/school-meals|publisher= World Food Programme.|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> Furthermore, 80% of these 66 million children are concentrated within just 20 countries. Additionally, 75 million school-age children (55% of them girls) do not attend school, with 47% of them living in [[sub-Saharan Africa]].<ref name="web.worldbank">{{cite web|year=2013|title=Education|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/EXTABOUTUS/0,,contentMDK:23262014~pagePK:51123644~piPK:329829~theSitePK:29708,00.html|publisher=The World Bank.|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> Thus, the need to reduce hunger while increasing school enrollment in these children is evident, and school feeding programs have been developed to target this multifaceted problem.
Schools have become a natural and convenient setting for the implementation of health and education interventions. School feeding is just one facet of school health initiatives, as other programs may include de-worming, [[HIV/AIDS]] prevention and education, and life and health skills education. Overall, school feeding programs have been shown to directly increase the educational and nutritional status of recipient children, and indirectly impact the economic and social lives of themselves and their family.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} Additionally, school feeding directly addresses the [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDGs) of reducing hunger by one-half, achieving universal primary education, and achieving gender parity in education by 2015.<ref name="MDG">{{cite web|year=2013|title=Millennium Development Goals|url=https://www.un.org/millenniumgoals/|publisher=The United Nations.|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref>
==Types of school feeding programs==
There are two main ways to distribute food through school feeding programs: on-site meals and take-home rations.<ref name="wfp" /> On-site meals are foods that are distributed to children while at school during morning and afternoon meal and snack times, which may include a bowl of porridge or nutrient-fortified crackers. Take-home rations are a collection of basic food items, such as a bag of rice and a bottle of cooking oil, which may be sent home and transferred to the families of children who regularly attend school.<ref name="wfp" />
While the food items needed for school feeding programs may be imported into the country from anywhere throughout the world, an increasing number of countries and organizations are looking to expand what is called "home-grown school feeding," which requires that provided food is produced and purchased within a country to the greatest extent possible. These programs provide an opportunity for children to receive improved nutrition and educational opportunities while also allowing smallholder farmers to benefit from access to a market with stable, structured, and predictable demand.<ref name="hg1">{{cite web|year=2013|title=Global Home Grown School Feeding|url=http://hgsf-global.org|publisher=The Partnership for Child Development|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="hg2">{{cite web|title=WFP Home Grown School Feeding|url=http://www.wfp.org/content/home-grown-school-feeding|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> The New Partnership for Africa's Development (NEPAD) guided governments in Sub-Saharan Africa to include home-grown school feeding as a critical intervention for the food security facet of the Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Programme (CAADP). Several countries, including Côte d'Ivoire, Ghana, Kenya, Mali and Nigeria are currently taking part in home-grown school feeding programs.<ref name="trialsjournal">{{cite web|last=Masset|first=Edoardo and Aulo Gelli.|year=2013|title=Improving community development by linking agriculture, nutrition and education: design of a randomised trial of "home-grown" school feeding in Mali|url=http://www.trialsjournal.com/content/14/1/55|publisher=Trials|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref>
==Approaches to school feeding==
===Country involvement in school feeding programs=== [[File:Vrindavan SMS-518.jpg|thumb|School feeding program in India]]
According to the International Food Policy Research Institute, there are five stages of school feeding. The first stage includes school feeding programs that rely mostly on external funding and implementation, while the last stage includes school feeding programs that rely mostly on internal government funding and implementation.<ref name=IFP>{{cite web|last=Bundy|first=Donald|title=Rethinking School Feeding - Directions in Development Paper|url=http://www.ifpri.org/sites/default/files/DBundyppt.pdf|publisher=International Food Policy Research Institute|year=2009|accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> Countries that are within the first stage include Afghanistan and Sudan, where country governments are unable to lead school feeding programs. Countries that are within the fifth stage include Chile and India, which have functional, country-led school feeding programs. For example, the Government of Chile has provided a school feeding program for over 40 years through the La Junta Nacional de Auxilio Escolar y Becas (National Board of School Assistance and Scholarships) through a public-private partnership.<ref name="winch">{{cite web|last=Winch|first=Rachel.|year=2011|title=International Approaches to School Feeding|url=http://foodaid.org/news/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/Rachel_Winch_International_Approaches_to_School_Feeding.pdf|publisher=US Food Aid and Security|accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> This program involves technology that allows food to be centrally mass-produced and then distributed across the country. Additionally, the Government of India has supported school feeding programs since 2001, when the country recognized Indians' Constitutional Right to Food.<ref name="winch"/> Countries that are in the middle of the stages, such as Kenya and Ecuador may have some but not all of the governmental policies, financial capacities, or institutional capacities to operate school feeding programs without external funding or implementation.
===Involvement of the World Food Programme===
In terms of external funding and implementation, the [[United Nations World Food Programme]] (WFP) is the world's leading provider of school feeding program financial contributions and program development. WFP currently provides school feeding resources to an average of 22 million children in school, about half of whom are girls, across 70 countries. The total financial contribution for these programs is almost USD$500 million per year.<ref name="wfp" /> Many governments work alongside WFP in school-feeding programs, though in countries where the government is non-functional or corrupt, WFP may work on its own or with other [[non-governmental organizations]]. The World Food Programme has estimated that US$3.2 billion is needed each year to feed the 66 million school-age children around the globe, an amount of US$50 per child.<ref name="wfp"/>
WFP has been working with governments around the world for over 45 years, but is shifting from a food aid organization to food assistance organization, working to move away from "individual, isolated projects to more strategic and comprehensive approaches".<ref name=standards>{{cite web|title=New Approach and Quality Standards|url=http://www.wfp.org/our-work/preventing-hunger/school-meals/new-approach-quality-standards|publisher=World Food Programme|accessdate=8 April 2013|year=2013}}</ref> To foster government ownership of school meals, WFP has implemented eight quality standards that guide the design and implementation of sustainable school meal programs: * A strategy for sustainability, * A national policy framework * Stable funding and budgeting * Needs-based, cost-effective quality programme design * Strong institutional arrangements for implementation, monitoring, and accountability * Strategy for local production and sourcing * Strong partnerships * Inter-sector coordination, and community participation and ownership.<ref name="standards"/>
==Benefits of school feeding==
===Nutrition and food security=== School meals have been shown to increase the nutritional status of school-age children in a variety of ways. For example, there is a notable reduction in malnutrition via diet diversification and an increased absorption of micronutrients. Overall, the amount of kilocalories in a child's diet is expanded when they are given nutritional resources that they would otherwise have little to no access to. By increasing the amount of nutrition a child receives at school, that child's family's nutrition status also increases as their familial demand and requirement for food is decreased.<ref name=lawson>{{cite web|last=Lawson|first=Ty M.|title=Impact of School Feeding Programs on Educational, Nutritional, and Agricultural Development Goals|url=http://ageconsearch.umn.edu/bitstream/142466/2/2012LawsonPlanB.pdf|publisher=Michigan State University|accessdate=18 March 2013|year=2012}}</ref> Targeted take-home rations therefore increase the nutrition of the family as a whole, and not just the members of a given family that are of primary-school age. However, criticisms of school meals' impacts on nutrition stem from the idea that increased nutrition through school meals is only a temporary fix and does not target the underlying causes of malnutrition, such as high food prices and poor food distribution systems that prevent [[food security]].<ref name="tomlin">{{cite web|last=Tomlinson|first=Mark|year=2007|title=School Feeding in East and Southern Africa: Improving Food Sovereignty or Photo Opportunity?|url=http://www.equinetafrica.org/bibl/docs/DIS46nutTOMLINSON.pdf|publisher=Regional Network for Equity in Health in Southern Africa|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref>
===Education=== [[File:Feeding Program (Mabalacat Resettlement Elementary School July 14, 2014).jpg|thumb|School feeding program in Mabalacat Resettlement Elementary School]] Education is a key component in school feeding programs and global development because overall, a more educated person has an increased amount of opportunities in life, earns more money, and has a higher standard of living than an uneducated individual.<ref name="SFworldbank">{{cite web|year=2012|title=Do School Feeding Programs Help Children?|url=https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/bitstream/handle/10986/10418/665440BRI0Scho00Box365769B00PUBLIC0.pdf?sequence=1|publisher=The World Bank|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> School meals greatly impact recipient children's education status by increasing school enrollment and attendance, decreasing drop-out rates, and improving cognitive abilities and learning achievements.<ref name="trialsjournal" /> Generally, sending children to a school in which school-meals are served offsets the financial and opportunity costs of schooling, and thus families are incentivized to send their children to school.<ref name="lawson"/> Additionally, school feeding programs may serve as an incentive for students to go to school to receive food rather than missing out on food by staying home.<ref name=pak>{{cite web|last=Ahmed|first=Touseef|title=Food for Education Improves Girls' Education: The Pakistan Girls' Education Programme|url=http://www.schoolsandhealth.org/sites/ffe/Key%20Information/Food%20for%20Education%20Improves%20Girls%E2%80%99%20Education__The%20Pakistan%20Girls%E2%80%99%20Education%20Programme.pdf|publisher=Schools and Health|accessdate=18 March 2013|year=2007|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The increased nutrition status of children, as a result of school feeding programs, also enhances students' cognitive abilities and performance in school.
===Gender equity=== School feeding programs have the capacity to increase gender equity in access to education, which allows for gender equity across all spheres of social and economic life. There are a variety of reasons that girls' education is impacted by factors on both the supply and demand side of schooling. These include gender-stereotyped curriculum and teaching practices, increased risks for girls' safety outside of the house, socio-cultural practices that cause girls' education to hold a very low value, and school infrastructure that is not suitable for girls.<ref name="pak"/> Due to the combination of such barriers, girls are disproportionately affected by the direct and [[opportunity cost]] of schooling, which prevents girls from very poor households from attending school.<ref name="pak"/> Opportunity costs for girls' education include lost time that would otherwise be spent doing household chores and [[care work]]. School feeding programs reduce the costs of sending girls to school and allow for an increased number of girls to be sent to school by their families. Furthermore, improvements in female literacy that come from increased education have been linked to declining rates of fertility, increased economic opportunities, and other markers of female empowerment.
==Drawbacks and challenges to school feeding==
While school feeding programs have a variety of positive impacts, there are some possible negative impacts these programs can cause. For example, school feeding programs can increase the cost of schooling by requiring that communities provide fire-wood for cooking as well as other items such as fresh-fruit, vegetables, and condiments. Additionally, communities are also expected to provide people who can cook these meals and maintain stores of all of the required food products, as well as kitchens and other fundamentals of meal provision.<ref name="trialsjournal" /> By causing a variety of needs and requirements to increase in a given community, the net benefit to a community from school feeding programs may be reduced.
School feeding programs are very context-specific, and each community's program must be altered based on the demographics, geography, and other patterns within and outside of schools. For this reason, there are a variety of challenges that emerge in the creation and implementation of school feeding programs. A successful program requires that countries: * Determine if school feeding is the most effective program to target needy children * Define program goals and outcomes * Select the type of food to serve * Determine a food procurement method * Plan for management, implementation, and monitoring within schools—and a variety of other concerns<ref name="scaling">{{cite web|year=2012|title=Scaling Up School Feeding|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/TOPICS/EXTEDUCATION/0,,contentMDK:22705274~menuPK:282424~pagePK:64020865~piPK:149114~theSitePK:282386,00.html|publisher=The World Bank and World Food Programme|accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref>
Because school feeding programs are community-specific and require a great deal of planning, the sustainability of school feeding programs is a main point of concern for many countries. Countries are very limited on the demands placed on the staff, resources, and infrastructure required for school-feeding programs, and often have to rely on outside financial and personnel help to continue programs for a significant amount of time.
==Results of school feeding programs in low-income countries==
Though school feeding produces a variety of anticipated impacts, as mentioned above, much research and evaluation is being done to determine the results of school feeding programs in low-income countries. School feeding program results are often context-specific, but lessons from a variety of communities can help evaluate school feeding program effectiveness. Researchers at the [[International Food Policy Research Institute]] have critically assessed evidence from developing countries to define preliminary results of these programs.<ref>{{cite book|last=Adelman|first=Sarah|title=How Effective Are Food for Education Programs? A Critical Assessment of the Evidence from Developing Countries|year=2008|publisher=International Food Policy Research Institute|url=http://www.ifpri.org/sites/default/files/pubs/pubs/fpreview/pv09/pv09.pdf|author2=Daniel Gilligan|author3=Kim Lehrer|accessdate=13 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514024942/http://www.ifpri.org/sites/default/files/pubs/pubs/fpreview/pv09/pv09.pdf|archivedate=14 May 2014|df=}}</ref> These assessments found that the timing of meals is not a critical factor in the positive effects on learning and cognition, and thus take-home rations can perform as well as in-school meals, and that in-school meals may even disrupt learning.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gilligan|first=Daniel|title=How Effective Are School Feeding Programs?|url=http://www.ifpri.org/sites/default/files/DGilliganppt.pdf|publisher=International Food Policy Research Institute|accessdate=13 April 2013|year=2009}}</ref> In some settings, take-home rations are more cost-effective than in-school meals, and the study argued that some country programs may be optimized by focusing resources on take-home rations. Additionally, it was found that in the study setting, school attendance improved learning more significantly than nutrition status improvements, but that school feeding programs encouraged attendance and still have a positive net result on education levels. In a study done by Patrick J. McEwan, it was shown that there is no evidence that higher-calorie meals positively impact school enrollment and attendance, first-grade enrollment age and grade repetition, and fourth-grade test scores over average-calorie school feeding meals in Chile's national program.<ref>{{cite journal|last=McEwan|first=Patrick|title=The impact of Chile's school feeding program on education outcomes|journal=Economics of Education Review|date=February 2013|volume=32|pages=122–139|url=http://academics.wellesley.edu/Economics/mcewan/PDF/meals.pdf|accessdate=13 April 2013|doi=10.1016/j.econedurev.2012.08.006}}</ref> Thus, McEwan's study suggested that Chilean policy, to produce significant positive results, should focus more on the nutritional composition of school meals, rather than caloric content alone.

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox government agency |name = Scottish Land Commission |native_name = {{lang-gd|Coimisean Fearainn na h-Alba}} |logo = Scottish_Land_Commission_logo.png |logo_caption = Scottish Land Commission logo |map = Scotland in the UK and Europe.svg |map_caption = Scotland in the UK and Europe |formed = {{start date and age|1 April 2017}} |agency_type = [[Public bodies of the Scottish Government|Executive non-departmental public body]] |keydocument1 = [[Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016]] |headquarters = Longman House, [[Inverness]], [[IV postcode area|IV1 1SF]] |jurisdiction = [[Scotland]] |coords = {{coord|57.4876|4.2267|display=ti}} |chief1_position = Chairman |chief1_name = Andrew Thin |chief2_position = Tenant Farming Commissioner |chief2_name = Bob McIntosh {{post-nominals|GBR|CBE}} |parent_department = [[Scottish Government]] |website = {{url|http://landcommission.gov.scot}} }}
The '''Scottish Land Commission''' ({{lang-gd|Coimisean Fearainn na h-Alba}}) was established by the [[Scottish Government]] following the passage of the [[Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016]] by the [[Scottish Parliament]]; the Commission also incorporates the work of the '''Tenant Farming Commissioner'''. The Lands Commissioners, who constitute the Commission, have functions relating to land in Scotland, so that they address issues which relate to [[Land tenure|ownership of land]], [[Land law|land rights]], [[Land management|management of land]], and [[Land use|use of land]]. The Tenant Farming Commissioner has the aim of improving the relationship between [[tenant farmer]]s and [[land owner]]s, and can create codes of practice, provide practical guidance, and must consult on such matters. The Tenant Farming Commissioner cannot be an agricultural landlord or agricultural tenant, and will develop codes of practice which are in addition to the law and the jurisdiction of the [[Scottish Land Court]].
The Scottish Land Commission is a body concerned with looking at the concentration of land ownership, land taxation, and effective use of land for the common good. The Commission will also provide some scrutiny of those laws and policies that relate to land within Scotland.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.holyrood.com/articles/news/roseanna-cunningham-land-commission-will-mean-end-“stop-start-nature-land-reform” |title=Roseanna Cunningham: Land Commission will mean an end to the “stop-start nature of land reform” |first=Liam |last=Kirkaldy |work=[[Holyrood (magazine)|Holyrood]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
==History== In 2013 [[Richard Lochhead]] {{postnominals|GBR|MSP}}, then [[Cabinet Secretary for the Rural Economy and Connectivity|Cabinet Secretary for Rural Affairs and the Environment]], announced the launch of the Agricultural Holdings Review, which would examine the situation of land ownership and use, tenant-owner relationships, and all of the relevant legislation. The Review published its final report in January 2015, and the recommendations were put out to consultation. <ref name="review">{{cite report | author = | author-link = | authors = | date = January 2015 | title = Review of Agricultural Holdings Legislation Final Report | url = http://www.gov.scot/Resource/0046/00468852.pdf | publisher = Scottish Government | format = PDF | location = Edinburgh | access-date = 25 April 2017 | quote = }}</ref>
In the final report Richard Lochead noted the importance of the relationships between landowners and tenants for the future of agriculture in Scotland, stating, {{Quote|What we heard confirms to us that the future of the sector depends on productive relationships between tenants and landlords based on mutual trust, respect and confidence in the sector.|Ministerial Forward|Review of Agricultural Holdings Legislation Final Report<ref name="review" />{{rp|3}}}}
Following the responses to the consultation the [[Scottish Government]] presented the ''Land Reform (Scotland) Bill'' to the [[Scottish Parliament]] on 22 June 2015. The Bill was passed by the Scottish Parliament on 16 March 2016, and received Royal Assent on 22 March 2016 becoming [[Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parliament.scot/parliamentarybusiness/Bills/90675.aspx|title=Land Reform (Scotland) Bill|date=18 June 2015|website=www.parliament.scot|access-date=25 April 2017}}</ref>
The Land Reform (Scotland) Bill was criticised during its passage by the [[Committees of the Scottish Parliament|Delegated Powers and Law Reform Committee]] of the Scottish Parliament on the basis that it granted a significant power to [[Scottish Ministers|Scottish Minister]] to implement much of the details of the Act through [[Scottish Statutory Instrument|secondary legislation]] and delegated powers. Turcan Connell identified concerns around the implementation of the Act and the amount of scrutiny the detailed law would receive.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.turcanconnell.com/media/constitutional-issues/scottish-land-reform/articles/2016/04/land-reform-update-april-2016/|title=Land Reform Update - April 2016|publisher=Turcan Connell|website=Turcan Connell|language=en|date=27 April 2016|access-date=25 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426055558/https://www.turcanconnell.com/media/constitutional-issues/scottish-land-reform/articles/2016/04/land-reform-update-april-2016/|archive-date=26 April 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 1 March 2016 concerns were also raised by Scottish Land and Estates about the passage of the Land Reform Bill, the body that represents Scotland's rural landowners, who felt that the good that landowners did was ignored in favour of "being radical". Scottish Land and Estates, further asserted that how land is used is as important as who owns that land. [[Aileen McLeod]] {{postnominals|GBR|MSP}}, as [[Cabinet Secretary for Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform|Minister for Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform]] addressed the members of Scottish Land and Estates, who recognised the expertise of land owners in managing land, affirming that the intention is bring about balance in the tenant/land owner relationship, and to ensure everyone who has stake in land ownership and management is involved. She stated the Bill was about spreading good practice around Scotland, {{Quote|There are many good examples of communities and landowners working together for mutual benefit, and a key aim of the Bill will be to encourage wider adoption of good practice. ... I recognise the expertise and role of land owners in managing land, and the contribution that many landowners make to our economy at both a local and national level.|Aileen McLeod|Speech to Scottish Land and Estates<ref name="mcleod-speed">{{Cite web|url=https://countryside-alliance.org/scot/ca-scotland-news/dr-aileen-mcleod-address-to-scottish-land-owners|title=Dr Aileen McLeod address to Scottish Land Owners - Scottish Countryside Alliance|website=countryside-alliance.org|language=en|date=1 March 2016|access-date=25 April 2017}}</ref> }}
Libby Brooks, writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper on 17 March 2016, reported dissatisfaction with the new law from the [[Scottish Green Party]] for not being radical enough. [[Andy Wightman]] {{postnominals|GBR|MSP}}, land reform spokesperson for the Scottish Green Party, was disappointed that the Land Reform (Scotland) Act did not outlaw the ownership of Scottish land by [[Offshore company|offshore companies]] in [[tax haven]]s. Brooks also reported dissatisfaction that the Act does not restrict the amount of land that can be owned by any one individual.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/scotland-blog/2016/mar/17/a-new-dawn-for-land-reform-in-scotland|title=A new dawn for land reform in Scotland?|last=Brooks|first=Libby|date=17 March 2016|work=The Guardian|access-date=25 April 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
The Commission was established by the Scottish Government on 1 April 2017 by ''The Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016 (Commencement <abbr>No.</abbr> 4, Transitional and Saving Provisions) Regulations 2016'' made under the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016.<ref name="establishment">{{cite legislation Scotland|type=ssi|year=2016|number=372|ssi=The Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016 (Commencement No. 4, Transitional and Saving Provisions) Regulations 2016}}</ref>
==Headquarters== It is headquartered at Longman House in [[Inverness]]. There is a staff of around twenty: five Land Commissioners, the Tenant Farming Commissioner and support staff. The interim chief executive officer was announced as Hilary Pearce, a civil servant in the Scottish government seconded to the post.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-37652824 |title=Inverness headquarters for Scottish Land Commission |work=[[BBC News]] |date=14 October 2016 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
==Commissioners== ===Nomination=== The first commissioners were proposed in November 2016: Andrew Thin, Professor David Adams, Lorne MacLeod, Sally Reynolds, Megan MacInnes and Bob McIntosh as the Tenant Farming Commissioner.<ref name="proposed">{{cite news |url=https://www.commonspace.scot/articles/9846/will-they-deliver-six-commissioners-proposed-advance-land-reform |title=Will they deliver? The six commissioners proposed to advance land reform |work=[[CommonSpace]] |date=11 November 2016 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
The nominated Commissioners were considered by the [[Committees of the Scottish Parliament|Environment, Climate Change, and Land Reform Committee]] of [[Scottish Parliament]], which reported on 8 December 2016, recommending that the Scottish Parliament approve the appointment of the Commissioners. Nonetheless, the Committee did recommend that Bob McIntosh, proposed Tenant Farming Commissioner, should resign from membership of the [[Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors]] to maintain the perception of impartiality; the Committee believed McIntosh was in good a position for building relationships with both landowners and tenants. The Committee also recommended that Lorne MacLeod stand down as Chairman of [[Community Land Scotland]] and as a director of community owned land on [[Eriskay]], and asked the Scottish Government to provide a date for when appointments to the Commission would be regulated by the [[Commissioner for Ethical Standards in Public Life in Scotland]].<ref name="committeeapproval">{{Cite report|url=http://www.parliament.scot/S5_Environment/Reports/ECCLRS052016R04.pdf|title=4th Report 2016 (Session 5): Appointment of the Scottish Land Commissioners and the Tenant Farming Commissioner|date=8 December 2016|website=parliament.scot|publisher=Scottish Parliament|access-date=25 April 2017}}</ref>
The Report of the Environment, Climate Change, and Land Reform Committee was noted by the Scottish Parliament on 13 December 2016, and approved the appointment of the Land Commissioners (including the Tenant Farming Commissioner).<ref name="parliamentapproval">{{Cite web|url=http://www.parliament.scot/parliamentarybusiness/28877.aspx?SearchType=Advance&ReferenceNumbers=S5M-03099| title=Motion S5M-03099: Appointment of Scottish Land Commissioners and the Tenant Farming Commissioner |series = Motions, Questions and Answers |department = Chamber Office|publisher=Scottish Parliament|date=15 December 2016|access-date=25 April 2017}}</ref>
===Chairman=== The first chairman, Andrew Thin, was previously the Scottish Government's Independent Advisor on Tenant Farming, and was involved in the establishment of the [[Cairngorms National Park|Cairngorms National Park Authority]] and had previously worked for [[Scottish Natural Heritage]].<ref name="thin">{{cite news|last1=Davidson|first1=Gordon|title=Scotland's first Land Commission appointed|url=http://www.thescottishfarmer.co.uk/news/14911953.Scotland_s_first_Land_Commission_appointed/|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=The Scottish Farmer|publisher=Newsquest Herald and Times Group Ltd|date=18 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
===Tenant Farming Commissioner=== The Tenant Farming Commissioner cannot be an agricultural landlord or agricultural tenant, and will develop codes of practice which are in addition to the law and the jurisdiction of the [[Scottish Land Court]]. The Tenant Farming Commissioner has the power to investigate breaches of the codes of practice.<ref name="gillespie">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gillespiemacandrew.co.uk/media/340813/land-reform-act-2016.pdf|title=A Brief Guide to Land Reform in Scotland - April 2016|last=Blair|first=Mike|date=April 2016|website=gillespiemacandrew.co.uk|publisher=Gillespie MacAndrew and Hunters Residential|format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170306131212/http://www.gillespiemacandrew.co.uk/media/340813/land-reform-act-2016.pdf|archive-date=6 March 2017|dead-url=yes|access-date=25 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
As reported in ''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]'' newspaper on 11 August 2016, Christopher Nicholson of the Scottish Tenant Farming Association stated that the creation of a Tenant Farming Commissioner had the support of both landowners and tenants.<ref name="news-settingup">{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/business/14674579.Process_of_setting_up_a_Scottish_Land_Commission_under_way/ |title=Process of setting up a Scottish Land Commission under way |first=Rog |last=Wood |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |date=11 August 2016 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> The Agriculture Holdings Review had identified examples of dysfunctional relationships between landlords and tenants, with Bob McIntosh stating, {{Quote|The Agriculture Holdings Review identified examples of dysfunctional landlord/tenant relationships based on a ‘them and us’ culture, so a culture change towards a more mutually beneficial partnership approach would represent success.|Bob McIntosh|Interview in ''The Scotsman'' - ''Co-operation is key for farm tenancy relationships''|<ref name="news-coop">{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/business/companies/farming/co-operation-is-key-for-farm-tenancy-relationships-1-4330606 |title=Co-operation is key for farm tenancy relationships |first=Brian |last=Henderson |work=[[The Scotsman]] |date=3 January 2017 |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>}}
The ''[[The Press and Journal (Scotland)|Press and Journal]]'' newspaper, reported on 8 April 2017 that Bob McIntosh, the first Tenant Farming Commissioner, was hoping that the Codes of Practice he would develop would help tenants and landowners to resolve disputes without recourse to the [[Scottish Land Court]]. He stated that he would be able to investigate instances where a landlord or tenant had not complied with the Codes of Practice, following the lodging of a formal complaint.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-press-and-journal-aberdeen/20170407/282183650905725|title=Rural Relationships in Focus|last=|first=|date=7 April 2017|website=www.pressreader.com|publisher=''[[The Press and Journal (Scotland)|Press and Journal]]'' newspaper|access-date=25 April 2017}}</ref>

{{Roman government}} The '''Senate of the Roman Kingdom''' was a political institution in the ancient [[Roman Kingdom]]. The word ''[[senate]]'' derives from the [[Latin]] word ''[[senex]]'', which means "old man". Therefore, ''senate'' literally means "board of old men" and translates as "Council of Elders". The prehistoric [[Proto-Indo-Europeans|Indo-Europeans]] who settled Rome in the centuries before the legendary founding of Rome in 753 BC<ref name="Abbott, 3">Abbott, 3</ref> were structured into tribal communities.<ref name="Abbott, 1">Abbott, 1</ref> These tribal communities often included an aristocratic board of tribal elders, who were vested with supreme authority over their tribe.<ref name="Abbott, 12">Abbott, 12</ref> The early tribes that had settled along the banks of the [[Tiber]] eventually aggregated into a loose confederation, and later formed an alliance for protection against invaders.
The early Romans were deeply patriarchal. The early Roman family was called a ''[[gens]]'' or "[[clan]]".<ref name="Abbott, 1">Abbott, 1</ref> Each clan was an aggregation of families under a common living male patriarch, called a ''[[Pater familias|pater]]'' (the Latin word for "father"). The ''pater'' was the undisputed master of his clan.<ref name="Abbott, 6">Abbott, 6</ref> He had the absolute power to resolve any disputes, and to make any decisions for the collective ''gens''. When the early Roman ''gens'' were aggregating to form a common community, the ''patres'' from the leading clans were selected<ref name="Abbott, 16">Abbott, 16</ref> for the confederated board of elders (what would become the [[Roman Senate]]).<ref name="Abbott, 6">Abbott, 6</ref> Legend states that the senate grew to a membership of 300 after three blocks of 100 senators were added at fixed points in time. What likely happened, however, was a gradual aggregation of ''patres'' over time, as more clans achieved high status.<ref name="Abbott, 16">Abbott, 16</ref> The early senate derived its ultimate sovereignty from the fact that it was composed of the patriarchal heads of the leading families. As the individual ''patres'' led their families, the board of ''patres'' led the confederation of those families. In time, the ''patres'' came to recognize the need for a single leader. Therefore, they elected a [[Executive Magistrates of the Roman Kingdom#The King of Rome|king]] (''rex''),<ref name="Abbott, 6">Abbott, 6</ref> and vested in him their sovereign power.<ref name="Byrd, 42">Byrd, 42</ref> The king presided over the senate, appointed individuals to the senate (for life), and expelled individuals from the senate. When the king died, his sovereign power naturally reverted to the ''patres''.<ref name="Abbott, 6">Abbott, 6</ref>
==Origin and Development==
According to [[Livy]], The senate was created by Rome's first king, [[Romulus]] and consisted of 100 men. The descendants of those 100 men subsequently became the [[Patrician (ancient Rome)|patrician]] class.<ref>[[Livy]], ''[[Ab Urbe Condita Libri (Livy)|Ab urbe condita]]'', 1:8</ref>
100 more were added to the Senate by Rome's fifth king, [[Lucius Tarquinius Priscus]], from amongst the minor leading families.<ref>[[Livy]], ''[[Ab Urbe Condita Libri (Livy)|Ab urbe condita]]'', 1:35</ref>
==Powers of the senate== The senate of the [[Roman Kingdom]] could only be convened by the king, and usually met in either a ''templum'', or in some other location that had been consecrated by a religious official (an [[augur]]).<ref name="Abbott, 17">Abbott, 17</ref> While the senate could pass "laws", it would be incorrect to view the "laws" passed during the time of the kingdom as legislation. In effect, these "laws" were actually the decrees of the king. The king had the absolute power to make any law. However, he often involved both the senate and the [[Legislative Assemblies of the Roman Kingdom#Curiate Assembly|popular assembly]] (the "Curiate Assembly") in the process. The primary role of the senate in this process was to either assist the king, or to provide additional legitimacy to a decree of the king by declaring its support. Sometimes this involved debate in the senate over the proposed law or an actual vote on the law. However, the king was free to ignore any ruling that the senate ultimately passed.<ref name="Abbott, 17">Abbott, 17</ref> In addition, during the days of the kingdom, the senate's limited prestige made it an accepted practice for the king to ignore advice handed down by the senate. The senate did, however, become an influential advisory council to the king. This tradition was maintained throughout the life of the Roman Republic, although in practice, the republican magistrates rarely acted against the wishes of the senate.<ref name="Abbott, 17">Abbott, 17</ref>
[[File:Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres 019.jpg|thumb|left|Romulus, Victor over Acron, hauls the rich booty to the temple of Jupiter, by [[Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres]]]] The ''[[patres]]'' that filled the ranks of the early senate held a position of absolute dominance over their respective families.<ref name="Abbott, 6">Abbott, 6</ref> Since the senate was filled with the ''patres'' of the leading families, their individual dominance over their individual families was consolidated into collective dominance over the collective families of the early Roman community. These were the original [[Patrician (ancient Rome)|patrician]] families.
While the king was technically elected by the people, it was actually the senate who chose each new king. Since the consolidated authority of the ''patres'' of the senate chose the king, the king became the embodiment of that authority. Since the authority of each ''patre'' over his family was absolute,<ref name="Abbott, 6">Abbott, 6</ref> the king was vested with the absolute authority over those families (and thus over the entire state). Since the king derived his authority from the ''patres'', he (theoretically) could not pass that power on to an heir upon his death. Thus, the authority reverted to the senate when the king died.
The period between the death of one king, and the election of a new king, was called the [[interregnum]].<ref name="Livy 1:17">[[Livy]], ''[[Ab Urbe Condita Libri (Livy)|Ab urbe condita]]'', 1:17</ref> The interregnum was the only period during which the senate exercised its sovereign power. During the first interregnum after the death of Romulus, the senate, comprised at that time of 100 men, arranged itself into ten [[decury|decuries]], and each [[decurio]] governed Rome for five days as [[interrex]]. The decurios continued to rotate the government amongst themselves for a year until the senate elected [[Numa Pompilius]] as king.<ref name="Livy 1:17"/>
The practice eventually evolved that, when a king died, it was a member of the senate (the Interrex) who nominated a candidate to replace the king.<ref name="Abbott, 14">Abbott, 14</ref> If the senate gave its approval, then in practice, the people were unlikely to reject the nominee.<ref name="Byrd, 20">Byrd, 20</ref> The formal election of the king by the people, however, did serve to confirm to the senate that the people (many of whom fought in the [[Roman army|armies]] that were commanded by the king) found their new potential [[commander-in-chief]] to be acceptable.<ref name="Abbott, 14">Abbott, 14</ref> After the senate gave its final approval, the Interrex declared the individual king, and then returned to the ranks of the senate.<ref name="Abbott, 14">Abbott, 14</ref> In effect, the senate chose the king, the people ratified that choice, and the senate finalized the decision.
